title: Megasphaera contributes to lactate-driven valerate production in the human gut - Microbiome
description: Background The human gut microbiota produces short-chain carboxylic acids (SCCA) through fermentation of undigested carbohydrates, and through chain elongation, a process that can be modulated through diet. Valerate is frequently recovered from human fecal samples, but little is known about dietary components, microbial contributors, and cross-feeding interactions that drive human intestinal valerate formation. We combined co-culture studies and in vitro human fecal microbiota batch fermentations (n = 20) with the analysis of a free-living cohort of obese and overweight women (n = 49) that monitored and modified (fermented) dairy consumption, to study the role of dairy-derived lactose and lactate in intestinal microbial formation of valerate. Results While the valerate producer Megasphaera elsdenii was not able to use lactose in single culture, valerate was formed (6.2 ± 1.3 mM) in co-culture with the lactose-utilizing and lactate-producing food microbe Streptococcus thermophilus. In vitro, valerate was produced by fecal microbiota of most donors (15/20) in control medium. Lactose addition significantly (p < 0.05) increased valerate formation of fecal microbiota that harbored Megasphaera at levels ≥ 5 log cells/mL (n = 4), while valerate formation was lower when Megasphaera was less abundant or not detected (n = 15). The addition of M. elsdenii to batch fermentations increased valerate production in 80% of samples and correlation analysis showed a positive correlation (p < 0.001) between relative abundance of Megasphaera and valerate levels. In vivo, 30% of study participants harbored Megasphaera based on 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing and species-specific qPCR. Diet supplementation with drained yogurt (skyr) led to higher fecal microbial diversity (p < 0.05) and relative abundance of Streptococcaceae. Participants that harbored Megasphaera and consumed skyr daily had significantly (p < 0.05) higher fecal valerate levels at week 6 compared to controls. In addition, fecal levels of lactate were higher in the skyr compared to the control group at 12 weeks. Linear discriminant analysis suggested co-occurrence of Megasphaera with the lactate-producer Lactobacillus and competition with other lactate utilizers such as the Anaerobutyricum hallii group. Conclusion This study brings forward new mechanistic understanding on the intestinal microbial formation of the SCCA valerate. Our findings identified Megasphaera as an infrequently occurring and low abundant keystone taxon contributing to lactose/lactate-driven valerate production in overweight/obese women. Our results highlight that the presence of Megasphaera affects the fermentative response to daily consumption of fermented dairy. Video Abstract
content:
Introduction

The human gut provides an ecosystem to a vast and diverse microbial community consisting of up to 1011 microorganisms [1]. The intestinal microbiome plays a critical role in maintaining and mediating health and disease through metabolic activities and interactions with the host [2]. The gut microbiota contributes to the hydrolysis of undigestible complex carbohydrates to release mono- and disaccharides that are available for fermentation. The short-chain carboxylic acids (SCCA) formate, succinate, lactate, and acetate are formed as fermentation intermediates and can be further metabolized to propionate and butyrate [3,4,5,6,7] (Fig. 1). Butyrate and propionate have well-documented health benefits through interaction with the intestinal immune system, as an energy source for colonocytes, and as compounds with antimicrobial properties [8]. While SCCA with n ≤ 4 carbons in the backbone structure are produced by fermentative pathways, SCCA with five (valerate) and six (caproate) carbons are formed by chain elongation [9] through condensation of an acceptor molecule, e.g., propionate or butyrate, and acetyl-CoA [10, 11] (Fig. 1). Valerate can also be formed as a result of Stickland reaction [12]. Valerate is frequently found in feces and has recently gained interest due to potential therapeutic effects. Restoring valerate levels improved health prognosis for patients with C. difficile infections [13], and did not alter overall community composition in an in vitro chemostat model and in vivo in mice [14]. Valerate conferred a protective role against Helicobacter pylori in mice [15], and was negatively correlated with the disease severity of ulcerative colitis in humans [16]. During infancy, low fecal levels of valerate have been associated with the development of food allergies at 1 and 3 years of age [17].

Despite its relationship with several positive health outcomes, there is limited research investigating the mechanisms of microbial valerate formation in the gut and few taxa capable of the production of valerate have been identified to date [18, 19]. The genus Megasphaera can produce valerate from lactate [20, 21] as well as from propionate [22]. Valerate formation has been reported in vitro for the species Megasphaera elsdenii, Megasphaera massiliensis, and Megasphaera hexanoica [23,24,25,26,27]. Megasphaera is a common inhabitant of mammalian gastrointestinal systems and isolates have been obtained from pigs, ruminants, and humans [28, 29], but little is known about the role of Megasphaera within the human gut microbiota. The valerate precursors lactate and propionate are produced intestinally through fermentation (Fig. 1) and can be obtained through the consumption of food [30] fermented by Lactobacillaceae and other lactate-producing food cultures such as Streptococcaceae [31]. Such fermented foods are consumed worldwide [31], and are relevant sources of dietary lactate [32]. There is surprisingly little information on dietary lactate absorption processes in humans. In addition, fermented food can contain fermentable carbohydrates and starter cultures able to form lactate during the gastrointestinal passage [33, 34].

To shed light on the interplay of dietary and microbially formed lactate, lactate-utilizing Megasphaera, and intestinal microbial valerate formation, we combined co-culture experiments and in vitro fecal microbiota batch fermentations. We modulated the lactate cross-feeding and valerate formation capacity of the system through the provision of the dairy sugar lactose, lactate, and/or Megasphaera. Additionally, we investigated the occurrence of Megasphaera and in vivo valerate formation using fecal samples collected during a 3-month dietary supplementation study of a free-living cohort of overweight/obese women that included the consumption of drained yogurt (skyr) containing lactate, lactose, and a lactate-forming starter culture, Streptococcus thermophilus [35].

Results and discussion

Valerate is produced by co-cultures of M. elsdenii and S. thermophilus in the presence of lactose

To test for lactate-driven cross-feeding activity leading to valerate production, we conducted co-culture studies of Megasphaera elsdenii DSM 20460 with the yogurt starter culture Streptococcus thermophilus LMG 18311 that produces lactate from lactose [33]. Digestion of lactose by brush‐border lactase phlorizin hydrolases and absorption take place in the small intestine. About 70% of the population worldwide are lactase non-persistent [33], allowing for lactose to reach the lower gastrointestinal tract. Strains were grown alone and in co-culture in anaerobically prepared yeast casitone (YC) medium that contained acetate, propionate, isobutyrate, isovalerate, and valerate (traditionally used term, fatty acids (FA)) [36] and that was additionally supplied with 40 mM lactose (YCFA-L) at 37 °C for 48 h. We measured turbidity using a McFarland densitometer as an indicator of growth and determined substrate utilization and metabolite formation using high-performance liquid chromatography with refractive index detector (HPLC-RI). Consumption and production were calculated as difference between levels determined at the individual time points and the original concentration at the beginning of incubation. We determined pH, which is indicative of the formation of SCCA during growth.

Within 48 h, S. thermophilus grew in YCFA-L (9.6 ± 1.0 MF units), used 25.6 ± 8.6 mM lactose, and accumulated 22.8 ± 3.0 mM galactose while producing 41.0 ± 9.0 mM lactate (Fig. 2A–B) leading to a final pH of 4.9 ± 0.1. When inoculated alone, M. elsdenii reached 3.3 ± 0.3 MF units (Fig. 2A) and produced minor amounts of butyrate (4.0 ± 0.5 mM), acetate (2.5 ± 4.5 mM), and lactate (1.2 ± 0.2 mM). Propionate present in the medium was used (− 1.9 ± 6.5 mM); the final pH was 6.0 ± 0.4 (Fig. 2C). The co-culture reached a turbidity of 10.6 ± 0.0 MF units (Fig. 2A), used 29.2 ± 5.9 mM lactose, and accumulated 27.7 ± 3.2 mM galactose. Butyrate (24.3 ± 1.5 mM) and valerate (6.2 ± 1.3 mM) were formed after 48 h inoculation, while propionate was consumed (− 5.1 ± 4.2 mM) (Fig. 2D). An accumulation of lactate (7.1 ± 1.7 mM) was only observed at 24 h (Fig. 2D), and the final pH was 5.5 ± 0.1.

Taken together, our results highlight efficient cross-feeding between a food-related lactate producer and M. elsdenii that yielded butyrate and valerate. In our study, M. elsdenii could not use the galactose that was released by S. thermophilus [37] even though some strains might have the potential to at least partly ferment galactose [23]. Prabhu et al. identified acetate and propionate as the main metabolites under batch conditions [38] while Yoshikawa et al. observed differences in propionate formation between strains [24]. Here, propionate did not accumulate when M. elsdenii was grown in single culture and in co-culture most likely due to direct chain elongation to valerate.

Valerate formation is a common trait of fecal microbiota in vitro

As our in vitro co-culture results indicated that M. elsdenii can produce valerate from lactate that was derived from cross-feeding, we conducted in vitro batch fermentations using fecal microbiota as inoculum to determine the valerate-forming capacity of Megasphaera within a complex community. We collected fecal slurries of healthy donors that were between 20 and 51 years old with regular eating patterns and bowel movements, which we considered as at least 3 meals/day, 7 days/week, and defecation once every 3 days to 3 times per day [39]. Donor microbiota D1–D20 were cultured in anaerobically prepared modified Macfarlane medium [40] without (MF-C) and with lactose addition (MF-L, 10 mM) to support lactate-based cross-feeding. Fermentations were initiated with a 1% (v/v) fecal slurry inoculum and incubated at 37 °C for 48 h (Fig. 3A). Substrate utilization and metabolite formation were analyzed with HPLC-RI. In vitro batch fermentations D1–D10 were also part of a previous study with a different aim [33].

In MF-L, the major part of lactose was consumed within 24 h of incubation (7.3 mM, 81%) and significantly more butyrate was produced at 24 and 48 h (p < 0.005) (Fig. 3B) in agreement with previous results [33]. As a high proportion of donor microbiota (15/20) produced valerate when grown in MF-C, our results suggest for the general potential of fecal microbiota to produce valerate. Unexpectantly, the addition of lactose to enforce lactate formation did not result in generally higher valerate levels, as median levels in MF-C were not significantly different from MF-L at 24 h and 48 h (Fig. 3B). In previous studies using a similar experimental set-up, lactate was formed during the first hours of fermentation [33] both in MF-C and MF-L allowing for the formation of valerate from lactate at both conditions. Valerate can alternatively be produced through Stickland reactions of proline [41, 42] or from valine, leucine, and isoleucine [43]. While in intestinal systems, SCCA with a carbon backbone n ≤ 4 are mostly derived from carbohydrate-driven fermentation [44], the predominant pathways for valerate formation have not been completely resolved.

Lactose reduced valerate levels of fecal microbiota when Megasphaera was not detectable or present at low abundance in vitro

To relate observations on valerate formation in vitro to microbial community composition and the occurrence of Megasphaera, we conducted 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing targeting the V3–V4 hypervariable region and determined abundance and occurrence of Megasphaera species by quantitative PCR. No biomass was collected from D3, and sequencing was not conducted.

At t = 0 h, community composition was similar in MF-C and MF-L (Suppl. Fig. S1A). After 48 h incubation, β-diversity of the microbial community was significantly different between donors and media (p < 0.05, PERMANOVA), but not between media only (MF-C versus MF-L) based on Bray–Curtis dissimilarity matrix (Suppl. Fig. S1B). Amplicon sequence variants (ASV) assigned to Megasphaera, Lactobacillus, and Bacteroides were variable loadings indicative for donor microbiota D5 and D11, while Escherichia-Shigella were indicative for donor microbiota D15, D19, and D20 (Suppl. Fig. S1B). After 48 h incubation, the most abundant genera in fecal fermentations in MF-C were Bacteroides (17.0%, IQR 13.7–26.8%) followed by unclassified Lachnospiraceae (6.9%, IQR 5.2–15.2%) and Bifidobacterium (6.4%, IQR 4.0–11.8%) (Suppl. Fig. S1A). The addition of lactose led to significantly higher relative abundance of Bifidobacterium (+ 5.1%, p < 0.05) and unclassified Lachnospiraceae (+ 3.0%, p < 0.05), while Bacteroides were significantly less abundant (− 4.2%, p < 0.05) (Suppl. Fig. S1A).

Megasphaera was detected in 21% of donor microbiota (n = 4) (Suppl. Fig. S1A). With additional BLASTn analysis of representative ASV, we identified M. elsdenii (ASV3, ASV8, AVS25, and ASV30) and M. massiliensis (ASV85, ASV114) as the species contributing to Megasphaera occurrence. Using qPCR assays targeting M. elsdenii and M. massiliensis, we confirmed results obtained by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing and identified four donors with initial Megasphaera counts ≥ 5 log cells/mL (D5, D6, D11, and D17), and 15 donors with low or undetectable abundance of Megasphaera (< 5 log cells/mL) at the beginning of batch fermentations.

After 48 h, the microbiota from four donors positive for Megasphaera had significantly higher valerate levels in MF-L (9.1, IQR 8.6–10.1 mM) compared to MF-C (6.9, IQR 6.7–7.9 mM) (paired t-test, p < 0.05) (Fig. 3C), while valerate levels of donor microbiota without detectable Megasphaera were lower in MF-L (1.0, IQR 0.1–5.1 mM) than MF-C (4.4, IQR 0.1–6.8 mM) (Fig. 3C). Within the microbiota from the four positive donors, counts of Megasphaera were higher in MF-L (8.2, IQR 7.6–8.5 log cells/mL, p = 0.095) compared to MF-C (7.2, IQR 6.4–8.0 log cells/mL) after 48 h fermentation (Fig. 3C). Valerate levels correlated positively with the relative abundance of Megasphaera (r = 0.37, p = 0.023) (Fig. 3C). Based on these results, valerate formation of fecal microbiota in the presence of lactose depended on the abundance of Megasphaera. These observations suggest a key role of the Megasphaera in directing valerate formation within a fecal microbial community in the presence of specific fermentable substrates, possibly with lactate as intermediate.

Supplementation of Megasphaera increased valerate formation in the presence of lactose

To further test the role of Megasphaera in the formation of valerate via lactose/lactate, we compared in vitro batch fermentation with donor microbiota D11 to D20 (n = 10) in MF-L to incubations that were additionally supplied with M. elsdenii DMS 20460 (1%) to MF-L at the beginning of fermentation (Fig. 3A).

At t = 0 h, the abundance of Megasphaera in batch cultures was below detection limit in most samples (Fig. 3D). The addition of M. elsdenii successfully modulated overall community composition (Suppl. Fig S1A) and increased median abundance of Megasphaera to 4.7, IQR 3.9–6.4 log cell/mL in MF-L + M. During fermentation, Megasphaera counts increased in 3/10 fermentations while valerate levels were higher in 80% of fermentations in MF-L + M (7.1, IQR 4.6–7.9 mM) compared to MF-L (5.5, IQR 0.0–6.8 mM, p = 0.2) (Fig. 3E). We performed correlation analysis of relative abundance of the 25 most abundant genera and the SCCA levels after 48 h incubation to investigate a possible link between members of the microbial community to valerate levels. There was a significant correlation between the genera Megasphaera (r = 0.6, p < 0.001), Lactobacillus, and Lachnospiraceae ND007 group (r = 0.4, p < 0.01) and valerate (Fig. 3F).

In previous studies, the addition of M. massiliensis to a synthetic consortium enabled the production of valerate [26], and lactate utilization could also be modulated in vivo in ruminants through the addition of M. elsdenii [25]. Our results suggest that also within complex human fecal microbiota, the transformation of lactate to valerate depended on the presence of Megasphaera.

The availability of lactate supports valerate formation if Megasphaera was present

Lactate is a key intermediate within the intestinal microbial fermentative network and several specialist microbes use lactate and acetate to form butyrate, e.g., Anaerobutyricum hallii and Anaerostipes caccae [45], which potentially compete with Megasphaera for lactate. To determine whether lactate-dependent valerate formation was related to Megasphaera occurrence, we performed additional in vitro batch fermentations with four donor microbiota, n = 3 without detectable Megasphaera (D12, D13, D18) and n = 1 with Megasphaera (D11). We cultured fecal samples in Macfarlane medium that was supplied with 8.4 mM of lactate (MF-Lac) or without (MF-C) and performed the same analyses as outlined before, including pH adjustment to avoid antimicrobial activity of lactate. The pH was recorded at 48 h.

After 48 h, the pH of MF-C (6.4 ± 0.1) was similar to MF-Lac (6.3 ± 0.2). While donor microbiota without Megasphaera (D12, D13, and D18) produced valerate in MF-C (8.1, 9.5, and 4.3 mM, respectively), there was no valerate detectable after incubation in MF-Lac. In contrast, D11 produced more valerate in MF-Lac (9.0 mM) compared to MF-C (5.9 mM) (Table 1). Our results suggest that the transformation of lactate to valerate within a complex microbiota depended on the presence of Megasphaera.

For D11, butyrate formation was higher in MF-Lac compared to MF-C (Δ8.3 mM) while propionate levels were lower (− Δ8.6 mM) (Table 1) indicating that valerate was formed on the expense of propionate, and that lactate addition also enhanced butyrate formation. For the other three donor microbiota D12, D13, and D18 that did not harbor Megasphaera, addition of lactate had comparatively less impact on butyrate and propionate formation. While previous literature reported that butyrate was the main metabolite formed in the presence of lactate [7, 11, 45], our results provide indication that lactate can also be transformed to valerate within a complex microbiota depending on the presence of Megasphaera.

Daily drained yogurt consumption increased Streptococcaceae relative abundance in a free-living cohort of overweight/obese women

To link our in vitro observations to in vivo data, we analyzed fecal samples from a free-living cohort study that was initially planned to investigate how overweight or obese women (body mass index (BMI) equal or above 25 kg/m2) responded to daily consumption of drained yogurt (skyr) [35, 63]. During the 12-week dietary supplementation, participants either consumed a breakfast consisting of skyr with oats (skyr group, n = 21), or an isocaloric dairy free breakfast (control group, n = 28). Participants were not required to stop (fermented) dairy consumption throughout the supplementation period. For this study, fecal samples from n = 49 participants (n = 28 and n = 21 in control and skyr group), were analyzed that were collected before (week 0), during (6 weeks), and after the study (12 weeks).

To study fecal microbiota composition in response to regular supplementary skyr consumption, we analyzed the microbial community using 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing targeting the V3–V4 hypervariable region. To account for a longitudinal study and repetitive measurements, we performed Kruskal–Wallis and post hoc Dunn’s test to compare between skyr and control group, and Friedman test with post hoc Wilcoxon test to identify significant changes during the study period within a treatment group.

Based on β-diversity analysis, dietary supplementation had a significant overall effect on the microbial communities (PERMANOVA, p < 0.05 (Fig. 4A), while α-diversity did not change during the study period (Fig. S2A–D). The most abundant families across all donors and sampling points were Lachnospiraceae (35.7%, IQR 30.2–44.3%), Ruminococcaceae (18.6%, IQR 15.1–22.5%), and Bacteroidaceae (7.8%, IQR 2.9–14.7%) (Fig. S2E). Streptococcaceae abundance was significantly higher in the skyr group at 6 (10.0-fold change, p < 0.05) and at 12 weeks (4.5-fold change, p < 0.05) compared to the control group (Fig. S2E). Within the skyr group, Streptococcaceae abundance significantly increased between baseline and week 6 and 12 (p < 0.05).

Our results show that a daily diet supplementation with drained yogurt in a cohort of overweight/obese women that were not restricted in the consumption of dairy enhanced the relative abundance of Streptococcaceae and changed β-diversity but did not alter the relative abundance of any other major microbial families. These results are in agreement with a previous study that reported few overall changes in fecal microbiota composition upon the daily consumption of skyr, but observed the successful transmission of the skyr starter culture through the gastrointestinal tract [46].

In vivo, Megasphaera was detected in fecal samples with little response to dairy consumption

Next, we examined for the presence of Megasphaera in the cohort and its response to dietary lactose/lactate uptake. Based on 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing, 13 participants (27%) harbored Megasphaera at any collection point of the study; at baseline, 18% of individuals (9/49) were identified as carriers of Megasphaera. We conducted BLASTn analysis of ASV classified as Megasphaera (ASV2073 to ASV2085), which indicated that M. massiliensis and M. elsdenii were the most abundant species in fecal microbial communities. According to qPCR targeting M. massiliensis and M. elsdenii, two more carriers were detected for a total of n = 15 (median 9.1, IQR 7.2–9.6 log cells/g feces) (Table 2). A similar proportion of Megasphaera positive participants was observed in fecal samples used for in vitro batch fermentations in this study and in other cohorts [47] highlighting the low representation of Megasphaera in the human gastrointestinal tract.

To account for the consumption of dairy products in addition to the skyr supplementation, we collected information on total dairy/milk consumption from a food frequency questionnaire that was collected at baseline (week 0) and at the end of the study (week 12). In addition to dietary supplementation with skyr (skyr group versus control), we differentiated participants as fermented dairy consumers including the skyr group, milk consumers, and consumer of dairy (milk and fermented dairy). Daily supplementation of skyr increased occurrence of Megasphaera from 4 to 6 participants, and there was also a non-significant increase in carriers of Megasphaera related to fermented dairy consumption (Table 2). In a previous study, Yazdi et al. classified Megasphaera among the taxa that prevailed in the treatment group throughout an intervention with drained yogurt (skyr) [46]. Similarly, Shuai et al. reported an increased abundance of Megasphaera in an intervention with high yogurt consumption [18]. In this study, we did not observe a significant change in occurrence and abundance but noticed that in few donors, Megasphaera became detectable after daily diet supplementation with skyr.

Daily diet supplementation with drained yogurt increased fecal valerate levels, also in carriers of Megasphaera

Next, we determined the impact of the daily skyr consumption on fecal fermentation metabolites including valerate. Fecal levels of major fermentation metabolites were determined by HPLC-RI. In feces, the predominant SCCA were acetate (35.7, IQR 26.6–47.1 µmol/g feces in skyr vs. 37.9, IQR 27.9–49.9 µmol/g feces in control), butyrate (11.8, IQR 8.2–15.6 µmol/g feces in skyr vs. 12.8, IQR 9.0–18.1 µmol/g feces in control), and propionate (4.4, IQR 0.8–8.3 µmol/g feces in skyr vs. 3.9, IQR 1.7–10.3 µmol/g feces in control), with no significant differences between diets or during the study within each group (Fig. 4B). There was a significant increase in total SCCA concentrations (acetate + butyrate + propionate) in the skyr group (∆week6-0 7.0, IQR − 3.0–17.4 µmol/g feces, p < 0.05) from week 0 to week 6 compared to the control group (∆week6-0 − 7.0, IQR − 15.9–8.2 µmol/g feces) (Fig. 4C). These observations correspond to previous studies that reported higher overall SCCA in fermented dairy consumers, in particular cheese, compared to non-consumers [48]. Moreover, changes in fecal levels SCCA profiles were observed in a similar cohort consuming skyr [46], linking the uptake of fermented dairy to intestinal fermentation activity.

Lactate levels were significantly higher in the skyr (4.8 IQR 3.1–7.6 µmol/g feces, p < 0.05) compared to the control group (3.1 µmol/g feces, IQR 2.6–4.7 µmol/g feces) (Fig. 4B) at week 12 as observed before by Yazdi et al. [46]. Fecal lactate could be derived through dietary lactate or because of the higher lactate formation capacity during skyr consumption containing lactose and the starter culture. Valerate levels significantly increased within the skyr group between week 0 (4.7, IQR 4.5–5.3 µmol/g feces) and week 6 (5.2, IQR 4.8–6.4 µmol/g feces, p < 0.05). At the same time, the increase in valerate levels was higher in the skyr group at week 6 (∆week6-0 0.5, IQR 0.1–3.2 µmol/g feces) compared to the control (∆week6-0 0.1, IQR − 0.5–0.7 µmol/g feces) (Fig. 4C). After 6 weeks, carriers of Megasphaera that were allocated to daily skyr supplementation produced significantly higher fecal levels of valerate (5.3, IQR 5.2–5.9 µmol/g feces) compared to the control group (5.0, IQR 4.6–5.1 µmol/g feces) (Wilconox test, p < 0.05). Together with the results observed in vitro, our data suggest that the presence of Megasphaera relates to the potential of intestinal microbiota to form valerate after the uptake of lactose/lactate containing fermented dairy. Higher fecal valerate were also observed after consumption of fermented vegetables [49], which indicates a general potential to modulate valerate levels with the consumption of lactate-containing fermented food.

Microbiota composition relates to the presence of Megasphaera

Cross-feeding activity of Megasphaera relies on the presence of functional groups delivering lactate. We performed linear discriminant analysis (LDA) [50] using the relative abundance data to identify taxa that distinguish between microbial community profiles that harbored or did not possess Megasphaera. We used results obtained by qPCR to classify microbial communities as Megasphaera positive or negative, and included 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing data sets collected after 48 h batch fermentation (in vitro) and from feces collected from the cohort data all three time-points (in vivo). Only LDA scores above 2 were considered relevant [51].

LDA analysis identified Negativicutes/Veillionellaceae/Megasphaera as discriminatory taxa (p < 0.01) between Megasphaera-positive and -negative microbiota in vitro and in vivo validating our initial classification (Table 3). Lactobacillaceae/Lactobacillus were enriched (p < 0.01) in Megasphaera-positive microbiota (Table 3) possibly because Megasphaera possibly benefits from a commensal relationship [3] with the lactate-producers Lactobacillus [52]. In pigs, both taxa Megasphaera and Lactobacillus increased in abundance after the consumption of fermented feed [53], and here we present a relationship for human fecal microbiota. In contrast, members of the order Oscillospirales/Ruminococcaceae/Faecalibacterium (Table 3) were more prominent in Megasphaera-negative microbiota. The genus Oscillibacter includes the valerate forming species Oscillibacter valericigenes [54], and in vitro, Oscillibacter was indicative of Megasphaera-negative microbiota (p < 0.01) (Table 3), possibly as an alternative taxon with the ability to produce valerate. In addition, the A. hallii group and Anaerostipes spp. were more prominent in Megasphaera-negative microbiota. Both groups contain members that produce butyrate from lactate [4], indicating that competition for lactate can shape the microbial community (Table 3).

Taken together, we observed the co-occurrence of Megasphaera with the lactate-producing genus Lactobacillus which can indicate a relevant cross-feeding scheme in the gut. Moreover, Megasphaera presence was linked to decreased abundance of genera related to lactate consumption, competing for the same substrate.

Conclusion

Our study identified Megasphaera as a taxon that only occurred in about 20–30% of adults and often at low abundance. Using an integrative and targeted experimental approach including in vitro assays and fecal microbial community modulation with lactose/lactate and Megasphaera, we provide mechanistic understanding on the contribution of Megasphaera to lactate-dependent cross-feeding in vitro. In vitro and in vivo in a free-living cohort of overweight/obese women that consumed fermented dairy, valerate levels increased significantly after lactose supplementation to fecal microbiota or daily lactose/lactate containing skyr consumption for 6 weeks, respectively. These observations indicate the potential of Megasphaera to respond to dietary lactose/lactate. We identified co-occurrence pattern of Megasphaera with the lactate-producing genus Lactobacillus, and possible competition with other lactate-utilizers. Together, our data attributes Megasphaera a pivotal role in fulfilling a specific function related to the uptake of fermented dairy in the host.

Materials and methods

Strains and cultivation conditions

S. thermophilus LMG 18311 was donated by Daniel Straume, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås, Norway, and was originally isolated from a commercial yogurt. M. elsdenii DMS 20460 was purchased from the German Collection of Microorganisms and Cell Cultures (DSMZ, Braunschweig, Germany).

S. thermophilus was routinely cultured using Todd-Hewitt glucose medium (THG) containing 3.7% (w/v) Todd-Hewitt powder and 44.4 mM glucose, or TH that was supplemented with lactose (THL, 10 mM). M. elsdenii was cultivated using Wilkin-Chalgren soya peptone medium (WCSP) or WCSP supplemented with lactate (WCSP-Lac, 10 mM). All media ingredients were purchased from Merck, Søborg, Denmark, unless otherwise stated.

Single and co-culture fermentations were performed in yeast extract casitone medium containing SCCA [36] and 40 mM lactose (YCFA-L). The composition of the medium per 100 mL was: 1 g of Casitone; 0.25 g of yeast extract; 0.4 g of NaHCO3; 0.1 g of cysteine; 0.045 g of K2HPO4; 0.045 g of KH2PO4; 0.09 g of NaCl; 0.009 g of MgSO4 · 7H2O; 0.009 g of CaCl2; 0.1 mg of resazurin; 1 mg of hemin; and a vitamin solution (MEM, 100x). A stock solution of SCCA was added for final concentrations of 33 mM acetate, 9 mM propionate, 1.2 mM iso-butyrate, 1.0 mM iso-valerate, and 1.0 mM valerate.

Fecal slurry fermentations were performed using a modified Macfarlane medium with enhanced buffer capacity as described previously [55]. This medium was designed to simulate the complex carbohydrate and nitrogen sources available in the large intestine [56] and contained additional SCCA [36]. The composition of the medium (g/L) in MilliQ water was as follows: 1.0 cellobiose, 1.0 xylan, 1.0 arabinogalactan, 0.5 inulin, 1.0 soluble starch, 3.0 amicase, 5.0 bacto tryptone, 1.5 meat extract, 4.5 yeast extract, 4.0 porcine mucin, 0.005 hemin, 0.4 bile salt, 3.0 KH₂PO₄, 9.0 NaHCO₃, 0.61 MgSO₄, 0.1 CaCl₂·2H₂O, 0.2 MnCl₂·4H₂O, 0.005 FeSO₄·7H₂O, 0.1 ZnSO₄·7H₂O, 4.5 NaCl, and 4.5 KCl. Tween 80 (1 mL) and SCCA were added for final concentrations of 33 mM acetate, 1 mM each of isobutyrate, isovalerate, and valerate, and 9 mM propionate. A proportion of the medium was supplemented with 10 mM lactose (MF-L) or 12.5 mM lactate (MF-Lac).

All media were prepared anaerobically. Briefly, the pH of the media was adjusted to 7.1 using 3.0 M NaOH, resulting in a final pH of approximately 6.5 after autoclaving. The medium was boiled for 15 min and after cooling, the medium was flushed with CO₂, followed by the addition of 0.5 g/L cysteine-HCl and 0.1 mL/L vitamin solution (MEM, 100x). Aliquots of 10 mL were dispensed into Hungate tubes or 20-mL serum flasks under a CO₂ flow. Tubes and flasks were sealed with butyl rubber stoppers and aluminum caps and autoclaved at 121 °C for 15 min.

To obtain working cultures, S. thermophilus and M. elsdenii derived from − 80 °C glycerol stocks were grown on THG and WCSP agar plates (1.5%) at 42 and 37 °C, respectively. Single colonies were picked for each individual experiment to obtain working cultures and incubated in WCSP for M. elsdenii or THG for S. thermophilus. After 24 h incubation, cultures were transferred to fresh medium for a 2nd incubation (2% v/v) in THL for S. thermophilus or WCSP-Lac for M. elsdenii. In all experiments, media composition and growth conditions were kept consistent across all experimental replicates. Working cultures were routinely checked under the microscope to ensure purity.

To perform co-culture assays, working cultures of S. thermophilus or M. elsdenii were inoculated at 1% (v/v) in YCFA-L. For comparison, both strains were also grown alone. Cultures were incubated at 37 °C and turbidity was measured with the McFarland Densitometer (Grant-Bio) at 0, 24, and 48 h of incubation. At the same time points, 1 mL culture was collected and centrifuged at 10,000 g for 4 min. Supernatant were stored at − 20 °C until further analysis. The experiment was run in three independent biological replicates from selected individual colonies. Working cultures were checked routinely under the microscope to ensure purity.

Donor recruitment and fecal sample processing for in vitro batch fermentations

Fresh fecal samples for in vitro batch fermentations were collected anonymously from healthy donors in 2023 and 2024. Collection and further processing are exempt from ethical approval according to the National Scientific Committee (National Videnskabsetisks Komite, NVK, Denmark). The donors were between 20 and 51 years old and had eating patterns (at least 3 meals/day, 7 days/week) and bowel movements (once every 3 days to 3 times per day), considered regular [39]. Donors did not take any food supplements containing prebiotics or probiotics nor used any medication affecting the gut transit, blood pressure, and digestion or antibiotics during the last 3 months preceding the sample donation. Additionally, the donors were not taking part in any weight loss diet/change in diet, present any intestinal discomfort, major operative intestinal intervention, or diseases that could affect the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., chronic inflammatory or autoimmune conditions). All donors provided written consent. In total, 20 fecal samples were collected (D1–D20), and samples D1–D10 were also used in the study of Li et al. [33].

Each fecal sample was immediately transferred to a sealed bag containing an anaerobic gas pack (BD) and was processed within 12 h of defecation. To prepare fecal slurries, all work was conducted in an anaerobic bench (Baker Ruskinn) to keep a strict anaerobic environment. Approximately 1 g of fresh fecal sample was added to a Hungate tube containing 10 mL anaerobically prepared peptone water (0.1% (m/v)). The samples were vortexed for 5 min to create a homogenous mixture. In vitro batch fermentations were initiated with freshly prepared fecal slurries as inoculum (1% (v/v)) using MF-C, MF-L, and MF-Lac; and another condition for which MF-L was additionally supplied with 1% working culture M. elsdenii (MF-L + M). Fermentations were run in single cultures or duplicates as indicates (Fig. 2A), for duplicates average values are presented. Flasks were placed in a shaking incubator at 140 r/m and 37 °C. Samples were collected after 0, 24, and 48 h of fermentation for further analyses and pH was recorded after 48 h. Supernatant and biomass from 1 mL sample were separated by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 10 min and stored at − 20 °C for analysis of fermentation metabolites and DNA isolation, respectively.

Microbiota analysis using 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing

DNA was isolated from the in vitro fecal slurry samples and from fecal samples collected from the cohort employing FastDNA Spin Kit for soil (MP Biomedicals). DNA was not isolated from the fermentation of D3 due to a lack of biomass. Microbiota profiling was conducted using 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing, following a two-step PCR method based on Illumina’s 16S Metagenomic Sequencing Library Preparation protocol as previously reported [40]. Briefly, the V3–V4 hypervariable region of the 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing was amplified using primers Bac341F (5′- TCG TCG GCA GCG TCA GAT GTG TAT AAG AGA CAG CCT ACG GGN GGC WGC AG-3′) and Bac805R (5′- GTC TCG TGG GCT CGG AGA TGT GTA TAA GAG ACA GGA CTA CHV GGG TAT CTA ATC C-3′) with adapters. The PCR mix consisted of 12.5 μL of 2 × KAPA HiFi HotStart readyMix (Roche), 0.5 μL each of forward and reverse primers, 1 μL DNA template, and 10.5 μL nuclease-free water. The initial PCR included 25 cycles of denaturation at 95 °C for 30 s, annealing at 55 °C for 30 s, and extension at 72 °C for 30 s, followed by a final extension at 72 °C for 5 min. A second PCR, using primers with barcodes, was performed for 8 additional cycles. The amplicons were purified using Ampure XP beads (Beckman Coulter, Denmark), and sequencing was carried out on a MiSeq sequencer (Illumina) at the Section of Microbiology, Aarhus University, according to standard Illumina protocols. Each run included negative control from a mock DNA isolation.

To process the reads, primer sequences were removed using cutadapt (v4.2) with the following parameters: -O 12 –discard-untrimmed -g CCTACGGGNGGCWGCAG -G GACTACHVGGGTATCTAATCC –pair-adapters –minimum-length 75 [57]. Only reads containing both primers and at least 75 bases were retained for downstream analysis. Quality filtering of reads was performed using the filterAndTrim function of the dada2 package, with parameters set to maxEE = 2, truncQ = 3, minLen = 150, trimRight = 40, and trimLeft = 40. Sample inference was conducted using the learnErrors and dada functions, with the pool = pseudo parameter [58]. Paired reads were merged using mergePairs, and chimeras were removed using removeBimeraDenovo (method = pooled). The resulting amplicon sequence variants (ASV) were taxonomically classified with the IDTAXA classifier [59] against the Silva SSU v138 database [60].

qPCR of members of the Megasphaera genus

The abundance M. massiliensis and M. elsdenii was determined using qPCR targeting the 16S rRNA gene. Primers targeting M. massiliensis were designed based on 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequences libraries derived in this study, and primers for M. elsdenii were obtained from a previous study [61]. Standard curves were generated using Linearized plasmids containing fragments of 16S rRNA gene of M. elsdenii type strain DSM 20460 or from M. massiliensis positive donors (Suppl. Table 1).

The qPCR master mix comprised 5 μL iTag Universal 2 × SYBR Green Supermix (Bio-Rad), 1 μL forward and reverse primer (Suppl. Table 1), 2 μL nuclease-free water, and 1 μL of diluted DNA, totalling 10 μL per reaction in a 96-well (low profile clear/clear) PCR plate, sealed with Microseal “B” Sealing film (both Bio-Rad). Each sample was run in duplicate, and each run included a standard and a negative control (nuclease-free water). Reactions were performed using a CFX Connect Real Time PCR system (Bio-Rad) as follows: hot-start activation at 95 °C for 3 min, followed by 40 cycles of denaturation at 95 °C for 10 s, annealing at 60 °C for 30 s, and melting curve analysis. Absolute cell abundance was determined accounting for multiple 16S rRNA gene amplicon copies of Megasphaera (n = 7) [62] (Suppl. Table 1).

Cohort and dietary analysis

Details of the cohort have been described previously [35, 63]. Briefly, a total of 75 overweight or obese women (BMI > 25 kg/m2) were allocated to consume either a fermented dairy-based drained yogurt, high-protein breakfast (skyr), or a bread-based low-protein breakfast (control) [35, 63]. The meals were isocaloric. The fermented dairy-based meal consisted of drained yogurt with oats and 150 mL of water, while the control meal consisted of a whole-grain toast with jam and 150 mL of juice. The supplementation study lasted 12 weeks with fecal sample collections at week 0, week 6, and week 12 [63]. In our study, only participants that provided three fecal samples were included (n = 49, 21 in the skyr and 28 in the control groups). Fecal samples were stored at − 80 °C until further use. Dietary records were collected at baseline and at the end of the study. In a food frequency questionnaire, participants were asked whether they had consumed dairy products such as yogurt, drained yogurt (skyr), sour milk with Lactobacillus acidophilus cultures, drinking yogurt, or similar products in the past month (yes/no answer). Additionally, participants were asked whether they had consumed milk (containing lactose) and/or fermented dairy products (containing lactose and/or lactate); participants who consumed milk were classified as “milk consumers,” while participants that consumed any type of fermented dairy including the skyr group were considered “fermented dairy consumers.” “Dairy consumers” included individuals who consumed both milk and fermented dairy.

Substrate and metabolite analysis

For the extraction of fermentation metabolites from fecal samples, 200–300 mg of material was mixed with 1 mL 5 mM H₂SO₄, vortexed, and centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 10 min. Supernatants from in vitro batch fermentation samples were obtained by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 4 min. All samples were filtered through a 0.45-μm polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) membrane filter prior to analysis. A dilution 1:3 was used for the fecal samples. Concentrations of SCCA (acetate, propionate, butyrate, lactate, succinate, and valerate) and of lactose, glucose, and galactose in fecal and fermentation samples were analyzed by HPLC-RI using an Agilent 1260 Infinity II LC system equipped with a refractive index detector (RID) and an Hi-Plex H column (300 × 7.7 mm) coupled with a guard column (50 × 7.7 mm). Samples were injected (10 μL), and compound were eluted using 5 mM H₂SO₄ at a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min at 40 °C. Quantification of fermentation metabolites was carried out using external standards.

Statistical analysis

For analysis of the 16S rRNA amplicon gene sequencing libraries, α-diversity was calculated using the microbiome package [64]. 16S rRNA reads were pruned and rarefied prior to use. In slurry, data pruning did not remove any taxa while for the cohort 267 taxa were removed. From cohort, a total of 1520 OTUs were removed after rarefication by depth while 208 OTUs were removed for the slurry data. Counts were used to calculate the richness and diversity indices (Chao1, Shannon, Evenness, and InverseSimpson) in RStudio. Since data was not normally distributed, Kruskal–Wallis and Dunn’s test were used to estimate differences of alpha diversity indices between diets [65]. Beta-diversity was calculated using Bray–Curtis dissimilarity matrix implemented in the R package MicrobiotaProcess [50]. Principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) ordination was used for visualization. “Adonis2” was used to identify differences between diet and/or time using PERMANOVA [66]. Correlation analysis between the relative abundance of the 25 most abundant genera and fermentation metabolites was performed with “rstatix” [65] package using Spearman correlation test. For linear discriminant analysis (LDA), we used the package MicrobiotaProcess [50] with the following setting: initial Kruskal–Wallis test with a p-value filtration of 0.05 and a second Wilcox test with a p-value filtration of 0.01. We included 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequence Libraries from all collection points of the cohort, and from 48 h incubation of the in vitro fecal microbiota batch fermentations. The LDA score that was considered significant was LDA > 2 [50].

To compare fecal levels of fermentation metabolites and the relative abundance of bacterial groups at different time points and in in vitro fecal fermentations, we used Kruskal–Wallis and Dunn’s test [65]. Changes in concentration of fecal fermentation metabolites or relative abundance within an study group over time were evaluated using the Friedman test adjusted by post hoc Wilcox paired test [65].
